The catalytic dimerization of acetylene to MVA represents a strategically significant pathway in coal chemistry valorization, offering a sustainable route for coal resource utilization. To overcome the poor stability of conventional Cu-based catalyst, a series of alkali metal (Li, Na, K, Mg, Ca) modified Cu-based catalysts were developed. Remarkably, alkali metal doping significantly enhanced both the stability and selectivity of the catalyst. In particular, the Cu-2Na-DMF/AC variant exhibited optimal catalytic performance. Material characterization and DFT calculation revealed that Na modification induced three key effects: (1) shortening of Cu-O bond lengths with concomitant strengthening of Cu-O bonds, thereby stabilizing the active site geometry; (2) reduction of the LUMO-HOMO energy gap, which facilitating electron transfer during the catalytic cycle; and (3) generation of a higher population of low-coordinated Cu(DMF)2Cl2 active sites. These modifications collectively enhanced catalytic efficiency by lowering MVA adsorption energy at active centers, promoting product desorption, and suppressing side reactions. Furthermore, the Na doping effectively inhibited copper species aggregation and leaching during catalysis, significantly improving catalyst stability. This work demonstrates a rational design strategy for optimizing Cu-based catalysts through alkali metal doping, providing an effective approach for stable and efficient MVA production. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Acetylene dimerization Cu-based catalysts Catalytic stability Alkali metal modification DFT calculation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Chloroprene rubber (CR) is a versatile polymer material with excellent physical and stable chemical properties[1–4]. The dimerization of acetylene to produce monovinylacetylene (MVA) is a crucial step in acetylene-based processes to produce CR, which is a prevailing trend that serves as an essential cornerstone in ensuring our energy security[5–7]. To overcome the shortcomings of traditional gas-liquid processes catalysts, such as low conversion and environmentally unfriendly, lots of investigations were focused on the solvent effects[8–11], ligand modification[12–15], metal additives[16–19], catalytic mechanism[20–23] and reaction kinetics[24,25]. However, the development of more stable and high-performance catalysts for acetylene dimerization is still urgently needed. Recent studies have shifted toward gas-solid reaction systems, which provide superior contact efficiency between acetylene and catalysts compared to conventional gas-liquid processes, along with advantages in catalyst preparation, separation, and regeneration. Li et al.[26] developed the Cu/AC catalyst with 48.3% acetylene conversion and 87.4% MVA selectivity, confirming the system viability. Furthermore, they suggested the Cu(I) species might serve as the primary active species in the catalytic system[27]. Song et al.[28] revealed that Brønsted acid sites on activated carbon significantly influence acetylene dimerization, where appropriate acidity improved catalytic activity while higher hydrogen concentrations effectively inhibited coke formation. In previous work[29], the DMF ligand modification effectively modulates the electronic environment, facilitated Cu(II) reducibility, and improved metal dispersion. Nevertheless, the poor stability still be remain challenges. Previous studies have found alkali metal could be effective electronic regulator with strong electron-donating capacity to enhance catalytic efficiency in critical reactions[30,31]. Extensive studies have revealed multifaceted promotional effects of alkali metals in catalytic systems: (1) in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, Na⁺ incorporation reduces Fe nanoparticle size, enhances CO chemisorption, and suppresses H2 adsorption[32]; (2) for Cu-zeolite catalysts, Na+ decreases methanol selectivity while increasing methane overoxidation tendency[33]; (3) in NOx reduction systems, Na⁺ regulates Cu redox properties, alters NO₂ formation pathway, and modifies catalyst acidity[34]. Advanced characterization reveals that Na/S co-modification facilitates alcohol formation[35], while Cu/Mg co-doping optimizes TM-O bond parameters and enhances redox reversibility[36]. These findings collectively establish that alkali metals not only modify active site electronic environments but also improve structural stability through synergistic metal interactions. Based on this, we propose an effective modulation strategy to enhance the catalytic activity by modifying the electronic structure of Cu-based catalyst with the electronic regulator alkali metal for the acetylene dimerization. On the one hand, it is would be expected that the formation of metallic synergies between alkali metals and Cu species could effectively stabilize the coordination structures and facilitate the construction of novel catalytic active domains. On the other hand, it is also would be hoped the incorporation of alkali metals could induce a pronounced electronic effect, leading to more Cu(I) species active sites. In this study, a series of alkali metal (Li, Na, K, Mg, and Ca) modified Cu-DMF/AC catalysts were prepared and the catalytic performance was evaluated in the gas-solid acetylene dimerization. Furthermore, density functional theory (DFT) calculations elucidate metal coordination structures, adsorption properties, highest-occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest-unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) orbitals, and active center charge distribution. The impact of the interaction between alkali metals and Cu species on the catalytic performance of Cu-based catalysts in the acetylene dimerization reaction was investigated through experiments and structural characterization. 2 Experimental 2.1 Experimental materials The coconut-shell-activated carbon (AC, 60-80 mesh) was procured from S. S. activated carbon industry science and technology Co., Ltd. copper (II) chloride dihydrate (CuCl2·2H2O, 98%), Iron chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O), Sodium chloride (NaCl), zinc chloride (ZnCl2), cobalt chloride (CoCl2·6H2O), lanthanum (III) chloride (LaCl3), nickel (II) chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6H2O), Lithium chloride (LiCl), Potassium chloride (KCl), Calcium chloride (CaCl2), magnesium chloride (MgCl2) was bought from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. All commercially accessible materials were of analytical grade and required no purification when used. 2.2 Catalysts Preparation A series of Cu-based/AC catalysts modified with alkali metals were synthesized via a two-step initial wet process. Alkali metal chloride (M = LiCl, NaCl, KCl, MgCl2 and CaCl2) was completely dissolved in distilled water and 4g of AC was added that stirred and dried at room temperature overnight. Then, CuCl2·2H2O (1.47g) was dissolved in the DMF-water solution was added the above mixture and magnetically stirred and dried overnight at 80°C. The obtained products were named Cu-M-DMF/AC catalysts. The Cu loading is 10%, and the Cu/M molar ratio is maintained at 10:1. Similarly, the Cu-xNa-DMF/AC catalysts (x = 1, 2, 3, 5, 7) were prepared by the same method. 2.3 Catalytic activity test Catalyst tests were conducted in a continuous fixed-bed flow microreactor under atmospheric pressure. Approximately 2 mL of catalyst sample was loaded into the tubular reactor. Prior to the reaction, a nitrogen purge pipeline was employed for 30 min to remove any moisture and air from the pipeline. The reaction temperature was heated to 100 °C, the reactant acetylene was supplied into the fixed-bed microreactor, and the gas mixture was injected into gas chromatograph (GC-2014C). The conversion of acetylene (X) and selectivity of MVA (S) were estimated as the following equation. X = [ ( 2 α 2 + 2 α 3 + 3 α 4 ) / ( α 1 + 2 α 2 + 2 α 3 + 3 α 4 ) × 100 % S = [ 2 α 2 / ( α 1 + 2 α 2 + 2 α 3 + 3 α 4 ) × 100 % Where α1, α2, α3, and α4 stand for the volume fractions of C2H2, MVA, 2-chloro-1,3-butadiene, and 1,5-hexadien-3-yne (DVA), respectively, in the gas products. 2.4 Characterization Methods The Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Laboratory's beamline 12-BM was used to carry out the transmission mode (fluorescent mode) X-ray absorption spectra (XAS) observations for the X-edge. Athena and Artemis software were used to examine the data from XANES and EXAFS. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were acquired using the Bruker INVENIO S spectrometer with KBr as the diluent. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were conducted using a DX-27mini diffraction spectrometer, equipped with monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm), and operated in the 2θ scan range of 10° to 80°. On a Multi-channel AMI Top-200 device, the BET surface region, pore volumes, and pore diameter of the catalysts were measured. The specific surface area (SBET) was calculated using the multi-point Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The catalysts were inspected with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed at room temperature with a monochrome Al Ka X-ray source (1486.6 eV) using a thermal Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer (Waltham, MA, USA). All binding energies were determined by the C 1s peak (BE = 284.8 eV) as a standard. Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Agilent 5110) was used to determine the amount of metal elements present in the catalysts. Images taken using a Titan G260-300 electron microscope operating at 200 kV are transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images. On a Micromeritics Auto Chem II 2920 instrument, hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were carried out in a micro-flow reactor with a 10.0% H2-Ar mixture. Using the integrated TCD signal as a baseline, CuO was used to calibrate the detector and measure hydrogen consumption. On the same apparatus, C2H2 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) profiles were obtained, a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to measure the amount of C2H2 that the sample produced. The TA TGA5500 thermogravimetric analyser (TG) from United States was carried out on the sample, measuring the amount of coke deposition on the used catalysts (under air atmosphere). The temperature was raised from 25 to 800°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Activity evaluation and mechanism exploration 3.1.1 Adsorption of C2H2 and dissociation of MVA In this work, all DFT calculations including adsorption and electronic properties were executed using the Gaussian09 package and the same accuracy described below[37]. The B3LYP functional is used for the calculation, and 6-31+G** base groups are used for the Li, Na, C, N, O, Cl and H elements. Considering the strong relativistic effect of Cu, K, Mg and Ca elements, the Lanl2dz pseudo-potential was adopted for the valence electrons, and its core electrons were represented by the Lanl2dz effective core potential (ECP). The relative energies of all structures presented in this work were zero-point energies (ZPE) obtained from frequency calculations at the same level of optimization. To obtain more accurately results of the weak interaction between catalyst and adsorbent molecules, the DFT-D3BJ proposed by Grimme et al.[38] was used to correct the energy. The adsorption energy (Eads) is calculated using the following expression: (1.1) E a d s = E C 2 H 2 + C a t − ( E C 2 H 2 + E C a t ) Where, E C2H2+cat, E C2H2 and E Cat represent the energy of the complex adsorbing C2H2 and catalyst, adsorbent C2H2 molecule and catalyst molecule, respectively. To gain a deeper insight into the adsorption capacity of the Cu-M-DMF/AC (M= Li, Na, K, Mg, and Ca) catalysts for both the reactant C2H2 and the desired product MVA, the separate DFT calculations were performed. The adsorption energies and preferred adsorption sites on all catalysts are summarized in Fig. 1 and Fig. S1. Firstly, the adsorption energies of the reactant C2H2 and the target product MVA are compared to the above two model catalysts. The order of C2H2 adsorption energy on Cu-based catalysts is Cu-Ca-DMF/AC > Cu-K-DMF/AC > Cu-Na-DMF/AC > Cu-Li-DMF/AC > Cu-DMF/AC > Cu-Mg-DMF/AC. The order of MVA adsorption energy on Cu-based catalysts is Cu-Ca-DMF/AC > Cu-K-DMF/AC > Cu-Li-DMF/AC > Cu-DMF/AC > Cu-Na-DMF/AC. The results indicated a significant reduction in the adsorption energy of MVA on the Cu-Na-DMF/AC catalyst, which is more thermodynamically favorable that is well consistent with catalytic performance results (Fig. S2). 3.1.2 HOMO-LUMO analysis of C2H2 on Cu-based catalysts The nucleophilicity and electrophilicity of substrates have been previously demonstrated to be assessable through HOMO energy and LUMOs energy, while the reactivity of a reaction could be inferred from the energy gap between the HOMO and LUMO orbitals[39]. To further elucidate the impact of alkali metals on catalytic reactivity, a comparative study was conducted using DFT calculations to analyze the HOMO and LUMO energies of Cu-DMF/AC and Cu-M-DMF/AC catalysts (where M represents Li, Na, K, Mg or Ca). Fig. 2 and Fig. S3 showed the orbital shapes of the HOMOs and LUMOs in the ground state. These properties could be associated with elementary reactions such as oxidation and reduction, where the oxidation process involves electron removal from the HOMO, while the reduction process entails electron addition to the LUMO[32],[40]. The order of energy differences is as follows: Cu-DMF/AC > Cu-Mg-DMF/AC > Cu-Ca-DMF/AC > Cu-Li-DMF/AC > Cu-Na-DMF/AC > Cu-K-DMF/AC. The energy levels of the molecular orbitals in Cu-DMF/AC catalyst are -6.48 and -0.23 eV, with an energy difference of 6.25 eV. After alkali metal modification, the energy levels of the molecular orbitals in Cu-K-DMF/AC catalyst are -5.45 and -0.71 eV, with an energy difference of 4.74 eV, while for Cu-Na-DMF/AC catalyst, the energy levels of the molecular orbitals are 5.80 and-0.82 eV, with an energy difference of 4.98 eV, slightly higher than that of Cu-K-DMF/AC catalyst. In summary, after modification with alkali metals, the energy difference between the LUMO and HOMO orbitals of Cu-based catalysts is significantly reduced, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity of the catalyst. 3.1.3 Electronic factor analysis Meanwhile, the Mulliken charge analysis was employed to assess the electron-donating capacity of alkali metals (refer to Table 1 and Fig. 3 ). The results indicated a descending order in terms of the electron count on copper atoms within the active center: Cu-Ca-DMF/AC > Cu-K-DMF/AC > Cu-DMF/AC > Cu-Li-DMF/AC > Cu-Na-DMF/AC > Cu-K-DMF/AC. The modification of the Cu-DMF/AC catalyst with Ca leads to an increase in electron cloud density at the copper site in the active center, thereby enhancing stability of the Cu component at a higher oxidation state. The Ca doping effectively inhibits the reduction pathway from Cu(DMF)2Cl2 to Cu(DMF)2Cl, raising the activation energy barrier of the rate-limiting step. Therefore, the observed decrease in activity of the Cu-Ca-DMF/AC catalyst aligns with qualitative results obtained from performance tests (Fig. S2). The electropositive alkali metal adatom tends to interact with the more electronegative atomic O (electronegativity for O = 3.4, Cl = 3.0, C = 2.5, H = 2.2) in the adsorbate molecules. The electron transfer between the Na and Cu causes the O atom to move closer to the Cu atom, making the distance between O and Cu exhibits a decrease from 1.97 Å in the case of Cu-DMF/AC catalyst to 1.88 Å for Cu-Na-DMF/AC catalyst. The results indicated that the metal additive Na species could enhance the structural stability of Cu-based catalysts through synergistic effects between metals. In summary, the coordination structure, adsorption performance, HOMO-LUMO orbitals, and active site charge distribution of Cu-DMF/AC and Cu-M-DMF/AC (M = Li, Na, K, Mg, and Ca) catalysts were elucidated in detail. According to the DFT results, the incorporation of NaCl leaded to a significant reduction in the energy difference between LUMO and HOMO orbitals, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity. Na modification shortened Cu-O and enhanced Cu-O bonding energy, which improves the Cu-DMF coordination structure stability. Through the synergistic interaction between two metals, reducing the adsorption energy of MVA on the active center and then promoting the MVA dissociation. 3.2 Catalytic performance tests The performance test and DFT calculation results showed that the addition of NaCl could significantly enhance the activity and stability of the catalyst. Therefore, it is imperative to investigate the impact of additive NaCl on the catalytic performance and structure of Cu-based catalysts through experiments. The synthesis procedure of Cu-xNa-DMF/AC (x=1, 2, 3, 5, 7) catalysts and the catalytic performance in acetylene dimerization were illustrated in Fig. 4 . It is evident that the Cu-DMF/AC catalyst was only 30% C2H2 conversion and 56% MVA selectivity after 20 h on stream. Conversely, the Cu-2Na-DMF/AC catalyst displayed significantly improved performance, achieving C2H2 conversion of 51% and an MVA selectivity of 87%. With the addition of Na additives, the catalytic performance decreased, mainly because the dispersion of the catalyst became worse due to excessive additives. The catalytic performance tests results verified that the incorporation of alkali metal Na additives could indeed enhance the catalytic performance of the Cu-based catalyst in the acetylene dimerization, which is consistent with the expected results. 3.3 Catalyst structure analysis To elucidate the influence of alkali metal Na additives on Cu-based catalysts coordination and reducibility, the X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) was studied. The Cu K-edge XANES spectra presented in Fig. 5 (a) and (b) exhibited the characteristic features of dehydrated Cu(II) species, as evidenced by: (1) a weak pre-edge feature at 8977 eV (A) corresponding to the dipole-forbidden 1s→3d transition, and (2) distinct shoulders at 8985 eV (C) and 9000 eV (D) corresponding to 1s→4p transitions[34]. Notably, the presence of a shoulder at 8985 eV (C) indicates partial reduction to Cu(I) species[41,42]. The EXAFS analysis (Fig. 5(c)) reveals that both catalysts exhibit coordination environments distinct from metallic Cu, CuO, CuPc, or Cu2O references, but closely resemble CuCl2 and Cu(OH)2 standards[43,44]. Quantitative fitting of the FT-EXAFS spectra (Table 1 and Table S1) identified two dominant coordination shells (Fig. 5(d-h)): a Cu-O/N path at ∼1.55 Å and a Cu-Cl path at ∼1.92 Å (uncorrected for phase shift effects). The coordination numbers decrease significantly upon Na additives incorporation, from 3.8±0.2 (Cu-O/N) and 1.8±0.1 (Cu-Cl) in Cu-DMF/AC to 2.8±0.2 and 1.3±0.1 in Cu-2Na-DMF/AC, respectively (Fig. S6)[45,46]. The decrease of coordination number, accompanied by shortened Cu-O bond lengths and enhanced bond energies[36,47], confirmed that Na additives promoted the formation of low-coordination, electron-deficient Cu sites. These findings align with the previous identification of Cu(DMF)2Cl2 as the active species[28], demonstrating that Na additives modification effectively increased the population of the active centers. To probe the atomic-level dispersion of Cu species, wavelet transform (WT) analysis of Cu K-edge EXAFS was conducted. The WT contour plots (Fig. 5(i-l) and Fig. S4) revealed two dominant features: (1) a primary intensity maximum at (5.0 Å⁻¹, 1.5 Å) were corresponded to Cu-O(DMF) coordination[34,48], and (2) a secondary feature at (5.8 Å⁻¹, 2.5 Å) were attributed to Cu-Cl scattering. Notably, the incorporation of Na additives could induce the systematic shift of scattering centers toward lower k-values, indicating modified local coordination environments. The attenuation of Cu-Cl signal intensity in Cu-2Na-DMF/AC correlates with increased Cl- concentration from Na addition, which competitively disrupts Cu-Cl coordination through two potential mechanisms: (1) steric hindrance induced by excess Cl⁻ ions, and (2) charge compensation effects that alter copper speciation. This finding aligned with the EXAFS fitting results (Table 2 ), which reduced Cu-Cl coordination numbers, confirming that Na modification preferentially stabilizes Cu-O coordination while weakening Cu-Cl interactions. 3.4 Physicochemical properties of Cu-based catalysts To elucidate the structural characteristics of the Cu-xNa-DMF/AC catalyst and gain deeper insight into the exceptional catalytic performance, a comprehensive set of physical characterizations were conducted. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) analysis indicated that the addition of Na additives had a negligible impact on the O-Cu coordination bonds in Cu-DMF/AC catalyst, while exerting a more pronounced influence on the C=C content (Fig. 6 (a)). This observation suggested that the high Na additives concentration that act as a potent dehydrating agent, which may have induced the formation of well-developed pore structures within the carbon matrix[31,49]. The XRD patterns of Cu-based catalysts as shown in Fig. S5 (a). All exhibit diffraction peaks corresponding to NaCl (JCPDS No. 05-0628), while no peaks related to Cu species were detected, indicating high dispersion or amorphous coordination with DMF[27]. As shown in Fig. 6(b), all samples exhibited reversible Langmuir type IV isotherms with H4-type hysteresis loops[50], indicating that the Na-modified Cu-DMF/AC catalysts maintain large-pore mesopores. The chemical valence states of Cu species of Cu-based catalysts were meticulously characterized via X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), as depicted in Fig. 6(c-d). The binding energy at 934.5 to 934.9 eV was confidently ascribed to Cu2+ species, whereas the adjacent range of 932.4-932.5 eV corresponded to the Cu⁺ and Cu0 species[51]. The Cu LMM X-ray absorption edge structure (XAES) spectra exhibited a salient transition feature at 910.5 eV, indicative of a unique electronic state, while the spectral signatures for Cu0 and Cu2+, along with Cu⁺, manifest at approximately 918.6 eV and 915.5 eV, respectively. The composition of Cu2+, Cu⁺, and Cu0 species was summarized in Table S2, which revealed that the initial Cu species distribution has unaffected by alkali metal Na additives. Furthermore, compared to the Cu-DMF/AC catalyst, a discernible negative shift in binding energy of Cu²⁺ species of Cu-Na-DMF/AC catalyst implied the charge transfer to Cu species. The XPS results indicated that the interaction between Na and Cu species that resulting in the increase of electron density of Cu sites, which was the key factor of the improvement of catalytic performance. Meanwhile, hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was adopted to investigate the effect of Na additives on the reduction of the Cu-based catalysts as presented in Fig. 6(e). All the H2-TPR profiles showed the reduction peaks at about 370°C was attributed to the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+and 474°C was assigned to the reduction of Cu+ to Cu0[50,52]. However, the the first reduction peak toward to lower temperature after the Na additives indicated the part of Cu2+ species was reduced at low temperature, which confirmed that the addition of Na additives enhanced the interaction of catalysts[53,54]. It is noteworthy that excessive C2H2 adsorption resulted in the deactivation of catalyst[55]. To systematically evaluate the influence of Na additives on acetylene adsorption, temperature-programmed desorption of C2H2 (C2H2-TPD) was employed. As illustrated in Fig. 6(f), all catalysts displayed two well-resolved desorption peaks. The low-temperature peak (Peak I) corresponded to weakly physiosorbed C2H2 on the AC support and π-bonded C2H2 species, whereas the high-temperature peak (Peak II) arises from strongly chemisorbed σ-bonded C2H2[48,56]. A pronounced desorption peak within 150-350°C was observed for Cu-based catalysts but complete absence of this peak in the Na-only control sample (10Na-DMF/AC), confirming that C₂H₂ adsorption is primarily mediated by Cu species, while Na species exert an inhibitory effect[55,57]. Quantitative analysis revealed that the C2H2 desorption area of Cu-DMF/AC significantly exceeds that of Cu-7Na-DMF/AC, demonstrating that Na incorporation reduced the C2H2 adsorption capacity. Strikingly, the C2H2 desorption peak of Cu-xNa-DMF/AC shifted to lower temperatures compared to Cu-DMF/AC, unequivocally indicating that Na additives weakened the C2H2 adsorption strength, which an observation corroborated with DFT calculations. These findings collectively demonstrated that the C2H2 adsorption properties of Cu-based catalysts could be precisely tuned by modulating the Na/Cu ratio that offered a strategic approach to optimize catalytic performance through balancing adsorption capacity and reactivity. 3.5 Surface analysis of the catalysts before and after the reaction Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) coupled with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was employed to systematically characterize the morphological evolution and structural properties of Cu species. Fig. 7 and Fig. S6 presented representative TEM micrographs and corresponding particle size distributions. TEM-EDS confirmed the atomic-level dispersion of Cu, with co-existing Na, Cl, N, and O species showing similar dispersion patterns without any detectable phase segregation or particle agglomeration. The mapping images of Cu and Na elements in the Cu-2Na-DMF/AC catalyst exhibited a high degree of overlap, indicating that both species are highly distributed on the support. The reduction in crystal size following the addition of Na additives provides evidence to mitigate aggregation among Cu species. For the used catalysts, severe aggregation of Cu species was observed in the Cu-DMF/AC catalyst which particle size increased from 5.8 nm to 9.6 nm. In contrast, the Cu species only increased slightly from 4.6 to 6.1 nm of the Cu-2Na-DMF/AC catalyst, indicating that the addition of alkali metals Na species effectively inhibited catalysts aggregation during the reaction due to the strong interaction[58],[59]. 3.6 Deactivation characterization of the catalysts As evidenced in Fig. 8 (a) and (b), the Cu2+/Cu+ ratio in the Cu-based catalysts was significant changed, suggesting the partial reduction of Cu2+ species to Cu+/Cu0 species by acetylene during the reaction. With increasing Na/Cu ratios, the acetylene adsorption capacity of the catalysts progressively diminishes that resulted in an elevated Cu2+/Cu+ ratio (Table S3), which coincided with the decline in acetylene chemisorption. The results indicated that the incorporation of Na additives modulated the electronic structure of active sites and adsorption performance that an optimal Cu2+/Cu+ molar ratio is critical for enhancing catalytic performance[60]. Furthermore, XPS results demonstrated that Na additives could effectively stabilize the oxidation state of copper species and mitigate excessive reduction of Cu2+ species to Cu+/Cu0 species, thereby improving catalytic performance. In Fig. 8(c), the diffraction peaks corresponding to CuCl species (JCPDS 06-0344) were clearly observed in the used Cu-DMF/AC sample with 2θ values at 28.49, 32.92, 47.43, and 56.28°. Notably, in the Cu-xNa-DMF/AC samples, no reflection peaks of CuCl (JCPDS 06-0344) were detected. Instead, only the amorphous diffraction peaks of NaCl (JCPDS No.05–0628) are present[61]. The XRD patterns results indicated that the addition of alkali metal Na additives could effectively inhibit the agglomeration of CuCl and facilitate the dispersion of Cu species. Previous research on the deactivation mechanism of CuCl2/AC catalyst have demonstrated that the formation of CuCl is detrimental to the reaction, as it promotes the production of the byproduct vinyl chloride[62]. Therefore, modification with alkali metal Na enhanced the selectivity to MVA[63], which is further confirmed by the stability measurement in Fig. 8(f) that the selectivity to MVA was steadily maintained at around 90%. Furthermore, the carbon deposition of the catalysts was measured by TG analysis, and the results are shown in Fig. 8(d), (e) and Table 3 . Below 104°C, the initial weight loss may be attributed to adsorbed water desorption. The weight loss in the temperature range of 104-241°C was attributed to the vaporization of DMF, which is further demonstrated by the TGA result of pure DMF[9,11,64]. For the Cu-DMF/AC catalyst, the surface carbon deposition was about 9.6%, and the Cu-2Na-DMF/AC catalyst showed a carbon deposition of only around 2.1%. These results suggest that NaCl modification effectively suppressed carbon deposition that is consistent with C2H2-TPD experimental data and DFT calculations. Finally, previous studies have indicated that the deactivation of Cu-based catalysts in the gas-solid acetylene dimerization reaction is primarily attributable to the loss of Cu species. To evaluate the influence of Na additive modification on the retention of Cu species in these catalysts, the Cu content in both fresh and used catalysts was quantitatively analyzed using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES). As summarized in Table 4 , the initial Cu loadings in the Cu-DMF/AC and Cu-2Na-DMF/AC catalysts were 9.33% and 9.45%, respectively. After 20 hours of reaction, the Cu content decreased to 4.86% and 8.01%, corresponding to Cu loss rates of 47.9% and 16.0%, respectively. These results demonstrated that the incorporation of Na additive could significantly suppress the leaching of Cu species. 4 Conclusions In this study, we developed an efficient bimetallic catalyst system for acetylene dimerization to MVA. Systematic performance evaluations revealed that alkali metal modification substantially enhances both the stability and selectivity over the control Cu-DMF/AC catalysts. Notably, the Cu-2Na-DMF/AC catalyst demonstrated optimal catalytic performance with about 60% C2H2 conversion and 91% MVA selectivity. Meanwhile, the advanced characterization techniques including EXAFS, TEM, and ICP-OES analyses revealed that the alkali metal Na modification induced significant structural modifications: reduced Cu-O coordination number and bond length, increased population of low-coordinated Cu(DMF)2Cl2 active sites, and effective suppressed aggregation, coke deposition and the loss of Cu species. These structural modifications collectively contribute to the observed enhancement in catalytic stability. Furthermore, the introduction of Na decreased the LUMO-HOMO energy gap, shortened and strengthened Cu-O bonds, created synergistic bimetallic effects that lower the MVA adsorption energy at active sites, and facilitates product desorption. This work establishes a novel strategy for constructing stable, low-coordination Cu active sites through alkali metal-mediated microenvironment engineering, successfully applied in the selective synthesis of MVA via acetylene dimerization. The findings provide valuable insights for rational design of high-performance bimetallic catalysts in alkyne conversion reactions. coredata.dc:description: Monovinylacetylene (MVA) is a key synthetic intermediate with extensive industrial applications. The catalytic dimerization of acetylene to MVA represents a strategically significant pathway in coal chemistry valorization, offering a sustainable route for coal resource utilization. To overcome the poor stability of conventional Cu-based catalyst, a series of alkali metal (Li, Na, K, Mg, Ca) modified Cu-based catalysts were developed. Remarkably, alkali metal doping significantly enhanced both the stability and selectivity of the catalyst. In particular, the Cu-2Na-DMF/AC variant exhibited optimal catalytic performance. Material characterization and DFT calculation revealed that Na modification induced three key effects: (1) shortening of Cu-O bond lengths with concomitant strengthening of Cu-O bonds, thereby stabilizing the active site geometry; (2) reduction of the LUMO-HOMO energy gap, which facilitating electron transfer during the catalytic cycle; and (3) generation of a higher population of low-coordinated Cu(DMF)2Cl2 active sites. These modifications collectively enhanced catalytic efficiency by lowering MVA adsorption energy at active centers, promoting product desorption, and suppressing side reactions. Furthermore, the Na doping effectively inhibited copper species aggregation and leaching during catalysis, significantly improving catalyst stability. This work demonstrates a rational design strategy for optimizing Cu-based catalysts through alkali metal doping, providing an effective approach for stable and efficient MVA production.
